Template report for sharing results of anthropometric survey
Summarizes demographics, data filtering automatically
Word format - easy for editing
Includes data quality parameters as well

title: Generating summary report, exporting z-scores data
text:
Exporting z-scores

Many times only prevalence is not the objective
Nutritional status as predictor or associated factor with some outcome
Need raw z-scores
Need computation of anthropometric indicator for further stratification
For further detailed analysis

title: Workshop on Anthropometric Data Analysis
text: First workshop is scheduled on 7 September 2022.

title: About
text:
Department of Community & Family Medicine
Department has been pivotal in imparting research methodology, epidemiology and biostatistics trainings. It has a set up a computer laboratory and conducted workshops for faculty and SRs of the institute. Faculty of the department has expertise in advanced data analysis particularly in the fields of nutritional data. Department also provides technical support to nutrition related public health programs in the state of Madhya Pradesh through CSAM wing of Regional Centre of Excellence for Nutritional Rehabilitation, Resource & Training.

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Anthropometric Indicators
Three key indicators

Weight-for-Age (up to 10 years)
Height-for-Age (5- 19 years)
BMI-for-Age (5-19 years)

Other indicators such as MUAC, Waist and Hip Circumference

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Available tools

who2007: a Shiny app for children ages 5–19 years, based on the WHO growth reference
WHO AnthroPlus software - For 5-19 years children
R package- anthroplus

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Practice Data set-3
Mandatory columns

id- Unique ID for each row
sex- Gender 1- Boys, 2-Girls
agemons- Age in months
weight- Weight in kgs and height- Height in cm

Other columns do not create problem

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text: WHO 2007 z-score calculator (CPEG App)

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
section: Upload csv dataset with preset names
text: Upload csv dataset with preset names

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
z-score outputs

zhfa- Height-for-Age (5- 19 years) (Stunting)
zwfa- Weight-for-Age (up to 10 years) (Underweight)
zbfa- BMI-for-Age (5-19 years) (Thinness)
flags- fhfa, fwfa, fbfa - extreme and non-plausible values

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
BMI-for-Age: Interpretation of cut-offs

Overweight: >+1SD (equivalent to BMI 25 kg/m2 at 19 years)
Obesity: >+2SD (equivalent to BMI 30 kg/m2 at 19 years)
Thinness: <-2SD
Severe thinness: <-3SD

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Weight-for-Age: Interpretation of cut-offs

Underweight: <-2SD
Severe Underweight: <-3SD

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Height-for-Age: Interpretation of cut-offs

Stunting: <-2SD
Severe Stunting: <-3SD

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Further analysis

Export z-scores through download button (adds columns as shown earlier)
Import in other program
Categorize indicators as per cut-offs
Do further analysis

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Demonstration with R package anthroplus

Install R software and RStudio IDE
Open RStudio
Open the R script for demonstration
Install required packages

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
anthroplus demo on R
Import data

# Load required packages (You should install them first and then you can load)
library(tidyverse)
library(anthroplus)

# Import dataset
df_anthro_plus_practice <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/drpakhare/Workshop-NDA/master/datasets_practice/3_dataset_practice_anthro_plus.csv")

View data

head(df_anthro_plus_practice)

  id sex Age agemons weight height District Cluster
1  1   1  19     228   66.0  173.4        2      42
2  2   1  17     204   65.0  164.8        2      68
3  3   1  19     228   63.0  164.0        2      54
4  4   1  17     204   63.0  168.8        3      90
5  5   1  18     216   61.5  164.0        3      84
6  6   1  18     216   61.0  163.1        2      64

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
z-score calculation

df_z_scores <- anthroplus_zscores(
  sex = df_anthro_plus_practice$sex,
  age_in_months = df_anthro_plus_practice$agemons,
  oedema = "n",
  height_in_cm = df_anthro_plus_practice$height,
  weight_in_kg = df_anthro_plus_practice$weight
)


df_z_scores is a dataframe containing z-scores


head(df_z_scores)

  age_in_months csex coedema     cbmi  zhfa zwfa  zbfa fhfa fwfa fbfa
1           228    1       n 21.95057 -0.43   NA -0.08    0   NA    0
2           204    1       n 23.93310 -1.36   NA  0.91    0   NA    0
3           228    1       n 23.42356 -1.72   NA  0.41    0   NA    0
4           204    1       n 22.11035 -0.83   NA  0.34    0   NA    0
5           216    1       n 22.86585 -1.63   NA  0.39    0   NA    0
6           216    1       n 22.93094 -1.75   NA  0.42    0   NA    0

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Export z-scores

write.csv(df_z_scores, file = "anthro_plus_z_scores.csv")

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Prevalence calculations

df_results <- anthroplus_prevalence(
  sex = df_anthro_plus_practice$sex,
  age_in_months = df_anthro_plus_practice$agemons,
  oedema = "n",
  height_in_cm = df_anthro_plus_practice$height,
  weight_in_kg = df_anthro_plus_practice$weight,
  sw = NULL,
  cluster = NULL,
  strata = NULL
)


Output or results are similar to Anthro Survey Analyser stored in a dataframe

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Output details
The result columns are coded with a prefix, a prevalence indicator and a suffix:
Prefix:
HA - Height-for-Age, WA- Weight-for-Age and BMI- BMI-for-Age
Prevalence indicator:
_3 : Prevalence corresponding to < -3 SD
_2 : Prevalence corresponding to < -2 SD
2 : Prevalence corresponding to > +2 SD
3 :Prevalence corresponding to > +3 SD

title: Computing z-scores for 5-19 years
text:
Output details
Suffix:
_pop : Weighted sample size
_unwpop : Unweighted sample size
_r : Mean/prevalence
_ll : lower 95% confidence interval limit
_ul : upper 95% confidence interval limit
_stdev : Standard Deviation
_se : Standard error

title: Datasets
text:
Preparing data for importing in anthro : This dataset has minimal variables and consist anthropometric data recorded by a surveyor as well as data of growth monitoring as recorded by AWW in her register. Participants will learn how to import data and map variables with this dataset.
Practice Dataset-2: This dataset has other variables like Location of Residence, Wealth Index, State etc. Participants will learn to obtain prevalence estimates among subgroups of these variables.
Practice dataset of adolescent anthropometry: This dataset consist of anthropometry data of adolescents (10-19) years. Participants will learn how to use Anthro-Plus and other tools to compute various indicators.
Data quality assessment: This dataset comprises anthropometry readings in children below 5 years. It will be used to demonstrate data quality assessment by using Anthro Survey Analyzer.

title: Resources
text:
Other Useful Tools
Canadian Pediatric Endocrine Group - Shiny Apps for Anthropometric Calculations

who2007: a Shiny app for children ages 5–19 years, based on the WHO growth reference
Growth chart plotter for WHO (for children 2–19 years) and US CDC (2–20 years)
Growth chart plotter for WHO for children 0–2 years
How to create csv files and calculate age in months in excel?



Growth Standards

WHO Growth Standards for 0-5 year Children
WHO Growth References for 5-19 years
Indian Academy of Pediatrics Growth Charts (0-18 years)
World Health Organization. Training Course on Child Growth Assessment



Additional interesting readings

WHO Technical Report : Physical status : the use of and interpretation of anthropometry, report of a WHO expert committee
The LMS method for constructing normalized growth standards(Cole 1990)
Demystifying LMS and BCPE Methods of Centile Estimation for Growth and Other Health Parameters (Indrayan 2014)
Revised IAP Growth Reference(Khadilkar et al. 2015)
Methods- WHO Growth Standards (0-5 years)(Borghi et al. 2006)
Methods-WHO school age and adolescent growth reference development(Onis et al. 2007)






References

Borghi, E., M. de Onis, C. Garza, J. Van den Broeck, E. A. Frongillo, L. Grummer-Strawn, S. Van Buuren, et al. 2006. “Construction of the World Health Organization Child Growth Standards: Selection of Methods for Attained Growth Curves.” Statistics in Medicine 25 (2): 247–65. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.2227.


Cole, T. J. 1990. “The LMS method for constructing normalized growth standards.” European Journal of Clinical Nutrition 44 (1): 45–60.


Indrayan, Abhaya. 2014. “Demystifying LMS and BCPE methods of centile estimation for growth and other health parameters.” Indian Pediatrics 51 (1): 37–43. https://doi.org/10.1007/s13312-014-0310-6.


Khadilkar, Vaman, Sangeeta Yadav, K. K. Agrawal, Suchit Tamboli, Monidipa Banerjee, Alice Cherian, Jagdish P. Goyal, et al. 2015. “Revised IAP Growth Charts for Height, Weight and Body Mass Index for 5- to 18-Year-Old Indian Children.” Indian Pediatrics 52 (1): 47–55. https://doi.org/10.1007/s13312-015-0566-5.


Onis, Mercedes de, Adelheid W Onyango, Elaine Borghi, Amani Siyam, Chizuru Nishida, and Jonathan Siekmann. 2007. “Development of a WHO Growth Reference for School-Aged Children and Adolescents.” Bulletin of the World Health Organization 85 (9): 660–67. https://doi.org/10.2471/BLT.07.043497.
